W L George George, Lionel Walter [1882-1926]. British author known for his popular fiction and writings on feminism. Author of The Intelligence of Woman (1916). Art of Courtship. Harper's 1923George, Lionel Walter. "The Art of Courtship." Harper's Bazar (January 1923): 212-218.
(Generalizations on courtship)
They do not apply to super emotional people,
to artists, . . or to the unduly intellectual
Such monsters must look after themselves
in the lists of love. . . . Success today
is no more likely than success a century
ago, unless one applies to courtship
a certain degree of low cunning.
(must give) to stony places a light
dressing of good earth.
Intelligently used poverty can be as
affective as wealth. . . Most women
are highly responsive to the attraction of
the arts, of letters, of music. They do
not understand them better than men
but they like them better. If he has no
wings . . . let him reserve for matrimony
the masc. privileges of crudity--& ignorance
¶ Assuming that he is reasonably young,
not too ill looking, not too poor, it may
almost be said that any man can wed
any woman . . . . She may be sorry
later that she has done so.
The brutal compliment is a splendid
weapon but it requires an education
of the voice, an eloquence of the glance
a dramatic mixture of audacity and
confusion. It had best be let
alone.
"The Art of Courtship" (see earlier note).In general it is inadvisable to refer to past rivals, even
to dead ones. Dead rivals are sometimes dangerous because
they have become ideals. If one could raise them from the
dead, they would be easier to manage. The main reason however
for not running down a rival even if he be druken or
faithless, is not so much that one enlists . . . . sympathy for
the under dog . . . . to depreciate a previous lover reflects on
her good taste. A certain amount of boasting is
desirable. . . . . Probably the best form consists in mock modesty,
because anything a human being says to another excites
contradiction . . . It is wrong to say, the boss wanted
to see me but I didn't go. I showed him the man I was.
This is shocking. Better say: The boss wanted
to see me. But I had an appointment with you.
The status of a lover should be shown indirectly & shld not
be concealed. The silent modest man never cut any
ice if anybody else happened to rush in with an ax.
The lover shd also avoid habits . . . They enable one
"The Art of Courtship" (see earlier note).to get more into one's life, but they seldom allow one to get
as much out. If he varies his suggestions he ceases to be 2
Dick who-takes-me to the theater . . . . . There is, it is true, an advanced
course for lovers, where habits are intentionally formed, so that
from time to time they may be broken, the object being to give pain.
. . . This shld not be done too early nor done too often,
nor done at all except by the clear headed.
A similar point arises on jealousy. . . . . women tho we
must today deal w a type of woman more intell . . . . than the
beautiful, selfish revengeful animal idiots idiots represented
by Shakes. Tenn., Homer Dante etc. Women did not
have a psychology until the 17th c. The awakening
of jealousy shld not be risked unless for the melting of an
emotional iceberg. Of gifts--I would say only 2 things,
the 2nd being very English. They shd be varied. The
2nd & English suggestion is: don't overdo it. Gifts are
made rare mainly by their rarity. Confidences are
essential but they shld be calculated. The lover shld
must have a past provided it is past . . . . A woman"The Art of Courtship" (see earlier note).
had better have only a present. A lover will do no harm
by occasionally sacrificing his beloved to his work. In my
notebook stands a case of a lover who went away to keep a
business appointment. She said I hate you for going
& I shld have hated you if you had broken a bus.
engagement on my account. You see this art of c needs some management

Leslie Nelson Jennings. Jennings, Leslie Nelson [1892-1972]. American poet and editor.
Bring me an herb of healing, bring me fruit
Cool from the hills, a charger heaped w snow;
Sea water chill & colorless and mute
In jars of smoky agate; let me know
Rigors of bronze, & all the frozen, white
Procession of lads & girls who stand
Stricken upon the threshold of delight,
Their limbs unloosened hand apart from hand!
These I will put between me and that hour
when Beauty learns to plague the eyes awake Perhaps anticipating MM's descriptions of beauty in paradise, in "Marriage"; Adam is "plagued" by some aspects.
With vague, moist mouths grown hungry to devourJennings, Leslie Nelson. "Interregnum" (see earlier note).
The honey of the heart. Oh, let me break
Into all rooms of worship or despair
And mercifully scatter ashes there!

Forum May 1923 Robt Bridges.Bridges, Robert [1844-1930]. English poet, who served as Poet Laureate from 1913 to 1930.
Poetic diction in English.Bridges, Robert. "Poetic Diction in English." 69 (May 1923): 1536-43.
It is difficult to dissociate the quality of Diction from
2 other matters, namely Properties & Keeping. Properties
is a term borrowed fr the stage . . . . The term
Bridges, Robert. "Poetic Diction in English" (see earlier note). Keeping is taken from Painting & has no convenient 10
synonym, but it may be explained as the harmonizing
of the artistic medium. . . . . no Property is
absurd if it is in Keeping. . . . . The higher
the poet's command of diction, the wider may
be the field of his Properties. Also, & this is a
very practical point, if a writer w no command
of imaginative diction should use such Properties
as are difficult of harmonization, he will
discredit both the Properties & the Diction.

Edith KingKing, Edith [1871-1962]. Poet born in South Africa, lived primarily in England.--Useful things p. 33
I'd like so very much to have
Some of the useful things
That lucky birds & beasts have got,
And first of all their wings;
For then into the apple-tree
I should not need to climb,
And graze my legs & tear my frock,
In getting down each time.
Then when the flies are troublesome
I'd like to have a tail,
And when I'm battling with the wasps
The beetle's coat of mail.
King, Edith. "Useful Things" (see previous note). When I am bathing in the sea
And find it hard to float, 11
I'd like to borrow from the duck
Her web & oily coat.
For thus provided I could live
On land in air or sea
And fly and flap & fight & float,
Just as it suited me.

She crossed the fleurs de leys;

Through flower & thorn Sir Unicorn
With pavon high drew nigh,
Till magic hop upon her lap

While I confess thy writings to be such,
--As nether Man, nor Muse, can praise too much.
Tis true, and all mens suffrage. But these wayes,
Were not the paths I meant unto thy praise;
For silliest ignorance on these may light,
Which, when it sounds at best, but echoes right;
Or blind Affection, which doth ne're advance
The truth but gropes and urgeth all by chance;
Or crafty Malice, might pretend this praise,
And thinke to ruine, where it seemed to raise.
These are, as some infamous Bawd or whore
Should praise a Matron: what could hurt her more?
But thou art proofe against them, and indeed
Above th' ill fortune if them, or the need.
I therefore will begin. Soule of the Age!

As sponges gather moisture from the earth
Whereon there is scarce any sign of dew;
As air infecteth salt: so at my birth

Not by reflexion and distinctly known,
But by their efficacy all mine own.

The other were occasioned by the fall.
A man that seemeth idle to the view
Of others, may the greatest business do.
Those acts which Adam in his Innocence
Performed, carry all the excellence.
Those outward busy Acts he knew not were
But meaner matters of a lower sphere.
Building of churches, giving to the poor,
In dust and ashes lying on the floor,

With visiting the sick, or governing
Traherne, Thomas. The Poetical Works (see earlier note). The rude and ignorant: this was a thing
As then unknown. For neither ignorance
Nor poverty, nor sickness did advance
Their banner in the world, till Sin came in.
Those therefore were occasioned all by Sin,
The first and only work he had to do,
Was in himself to feel his bliss, to view
His Sacred treasures, to admire, rejoice,
Sing praises with a sweet and heavenly voice,
See, prize, give hourly thanks within, and love,
Which is the high and only work above
Them all. . . . . .

Traherne, Thomas. The Poetical Works (see earlier note). 25
What powerful Spirit lives within!
What active Angel doth inhabit here!
What heavenly light inspires my skin,
Which doth so like a Deity appear!
A living Temple of all ages, I
Within me see
A Temple of Eternity!
All Kingdoms I descry
In me.

I was introduced to the glacial mannequin Mr. Cross gifted me six small cameleons, which resembled lizards, and one admirable cameleon, a fabulous prehistoric animal, a real chinese ornament passing from tender green to bronzed black, svelte and long. Like a lilly leaf and then suddenly swollen and stocky like a toad. It's eyes, in lorgnettes like those of lobsters, did not rely on one another. His right eye looked forward and his left eye looked backward. I was delighted, enthused by this gift." et aimé cette pure créature.

Spenser, Edmund. The Poetical Works of Spenser (see earlier note). Sonnet LVI
Fayre ye be sure but cruell & unkind,
As is a Tygre that with greedinesse
hunts after bloud, when he by chance doth find
a feeble beast, doth felly him oppress.
Fayre be ye sure that proud & pittilesse,
as is a storme that all things doth prostrate:--
finding a tree alone all comfortlesse,
beats on it strongly it to ruinate.
Fayre be ye sure, but hard and obstinate,
as is a rocke amidst the raging floods;
gaynst which a ship of succour desolate,
doth suffer wreck both of her selfe & goods.
That ship, that tree, and that same beast am I,
Whom ye doe wreck, doe ruine, and destroy.

E. Gordon Craig Craig, Edward Gordon [1872-1966]. English theater practitioner, including scene design and theory. MM writes of him in "Picking and Choosing" (Observations 1924) and refers to him in "The Dial: A Retrospect," Life and Letters To-Day 27 (1940). 44
Scene. Oxford University Press. 1923 25s/ Craig, Edward Gordon. Scene. London: Humphrey Milford; Oxford University Press, 1923.
There is a certain weary patience in Mr. Gordon
Craig's attitude toward the public. Because
what he has to say is so important, so valuable, and
so profoundly true, he does not expect to
make himself understood; still less does he expect
that more than half a dozen of the elect will
listen to him. . . . . a number of fine etchings of
remarkable draughtsmanship . . . . . A good deal of
graceful sword play to begin with, which Mr. Craig
sets forth . . . the ignorance & indifference . . . . of
the public; and then presuming we choose to
be one of the six who are able to understand
and willing to listen, the writer takes us
generously & painstakingly into his confidence.

Trivia 245. If where Fleet-ditch w muddy current flows,
You chance to roam; where oyster tubs in rows
Are rang'd beside the posts; there stay thy taste;
The damsel's knife the gaping shell commands,
While the salt liquor streams between her hands.
The man had sure a palate cover'd o'er
With brass or steel, that on the rocky shore
First broke the oozy oyster's pearly coat,
And risk'd the living morsel down his throat
What will not luxury taste? Earth, sea, & air,
Are daily ransack'd for the bill of fare.

Nursery Rhymes With Drawings by Leslie Brooke (see earlier note). He rode till he came to my Lady Mouse hall
Kitty alone, :
and there he did both knock & call;
etc.
Quoth he "Miss Mouse, I'm come to thee,
To see if thou canst fancy me;
Quoth she, Answer I'll give you none,
until my Uncle Rat come home;
And when her Uncle Rat came home
who's been here since I've been gone?
Sir (theres been) a worthy gentleman
That's been here since you've been gone.

And there he met with a dainty duck
This duck she swallowed him up with a pluck,
So there's an end of my history book
The hart he loves the high wood
The hare she loves the hill
The knight he loves his bright sword,
The lady--loves her will.

Hardy, Thomas. "An Ancient to Ancients" (see earlier note). And cracks creep; worms have fed upon
The doors. Yea! sprightlier times were then
Than now, with harps and tabrets gone,
Gentlemen!
Where once we rowed, where once we sailed,
Gentlemen.
And damsels took the tiller, veiled
Against too strong a stare (God wot
Their fancy, then or anywhen!)
Upon that shore we are clean forgot,
Gentlemen!
We have lost somewhat of that, afar & near,
Gentlemen,
The thinning of our ranks each year
Affords a hint we are nigh undone,
That we shall not be ever again
The marked of many, loved of one.
Gentlemen.
